. Drawille requires a font which includes the braille unicode characters and a unicode capable terminal.
You can test your configuration with this command: python -c 'print unichr(0x28ff)'. It prints ⣿.
. thanks!
. Python drawille displays the pixels in relative positioning by default. You can specify the frame's min/max coords by passing min_x, min_y, max_x, max_y numbers to it, so print(c.frame(min_x=0, min_y=0)) can do the desired behavior.
. =)

. @darxtrix getTerminalSize() measures the terminal size in characters, but drawille has 4x2 pixel for each character. That's why the line's width in the screenshot is exactly the half of your terminal's width.
Multiply the width by 2 and the height by 4 and it will produce the desired output.. Thanks, it's in the README.md. Great, thanks. great, thanks!

Foggalong:
What's the difference between AGPL and GPL? I thought the GPL was generally quite relaxed.
. I'm not sure I see what's wrong with that. If a project is using your code then surely they should respect how you want that code to be treated? I should clarify that I don't know much about licensing but when I read [http://choosealicense.com/] it seemed like GPLv3 was the best for ensuring collaboration so I've since licensed pretty much everything I've done with it. I hope I've not made a big mistake :/
. Just to be clear I'm not accusing anything or saying I'm right - I know next to nothing about this, so I'm keen to know more. I'll definitely read that!

I should clarify that I don't know much about licensing but when I read [http://choosealicense.com/] it seemed like GPLv3 was the best for ensuring collaboration so I've since licensed pretty much everything I've done with it. vmalloc:
First, GPL (at least v3) is not relaxed at all - it is very strict in the fact that it forces any project using via importing your code to be no less than GPL. This means that a project that uses MIT or BSD (which are much more relaxed) now has to change to GPLv3. Many organizations, fearing this viral licensing semantics, take an extra cautionary step and avoid GPL in their platforms. 
AGPL is even more restricting, as it considers "interacting over the network" as interfacing, and not just importing the code. 
—
Rotem
On Wed, May 14, 2014 at 6:00 PM, Joshua Fogg notifications@github.com
wrote:

What's the difference between AGPL and GPL? I thought the GPL was generally quite relaxed.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
https://github.com/asciimoo/drawille/issues/6#issuecomment-43091665
. I completely respect your choices regarding publishing your work. It is your choice to make. 

I just wanted to know if this choice had a specific reasoning behind it. 
I think Armin's post describes my feelings about AGPL/GPL pretty well: http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2013/7/23/licensing/
—
Rotem
On Wed, May 14, 2014 at 6:18 PM, Joshua Fogg notifications@github.com
wrote:

I'm not sure I see what's wrong with that. If a project is using your code then surely they should respect how you want that code to be treated? I should clarify that I don't know much about licensing but when I read [http://choosealicense.com/] it seemed like GPLv3 was the best for ensuring collaboration so I've since licensed pretty much everything I've done with it. I hope I've not made a big mistake :/
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
https://github.com/asciimoo/drawille/issues/6#issuecomment-43094361
. Just pointing out that, given what node-drawille has written in its README, it is a bit problematic licensing-wise. Claiming that one piece of software is based on another (or a port of another) is considered by many as 'derived work' (and I'm pretty sure RMS would say the same :-). 
—
Rotem

On Fri, May 16, 2014 at 7:37 PM, Adam Tauber notifications@github.com
wrote:

I belive in the freedom (of code), that's why i choose AGPL, but it isn't really hard to reimplement drawille in other languages or with different license (e.g. @madbence's https://github.com/madbence/node-drawille).
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
https://github.com/asciimoo/drawille/issues/6#issuecomment-43352484
. First of all calm yourself down. We're in no way attacking the developer, we're just trying to advise a better choice of license. 

I myself DID go through official copyright review with lawyers, and I can tell you for sure that this is a gray area. Reimplementing existing code in a different language (and take a look at the reimplementation please, it is not independent) can easily be dragged to court and proved derived work. This has nothing to do with patents.
But all of this is outside the original point. What you (and the original developer) are trying to say here is that they're fine with such a use such as node-drawille, and he approves of it. This is where I detect the contradiction I was pointing out. The developer is not very opinionated about copyleft issues, but chose a very strict license with regards to it (AGPL is even stricter than GPL about that, may I remind you). It's a free worlds and the developer can do whatever he wants. However he (and you too) should be open to criticism about that choice of license.
. Wow I was sure I knew stuff before, but since you just told me I don't know anything about copyright you must be right.
. And I didn't not ask to reopen the thread. I was fine with the original answer. This is not FUD - I did not go out campaigning for my cause ffs.
. I tend to take software licensing seriously. You obviously do not and that's ok. 
The reason I say this is that once a piece of code is licensed in some manner it opens up a lot if possible future entanglements with the law, even if the original intention was good. 
People got in more trouble over lesser actions than stating that a project is a port of another project in the README. Perhaps I was exaggerating with the word "illegal" but that doesn't make my point invalid, even if you wish it to. 
—
Rotem

claar:
:+1: I agree with @vmalloc; too bad about the AGPL licensing. This is the sort of library that a whole host of other programs could make use of otherwise.
Yes, node-drawille appears to be illegally licensed MIT. Its readme states "Basically it's a port of drawille by @asciimoo".  The AGPL is clear about programs based on an AGPL-licensed program. If node-drawille really is a clean-room implementation of the same problem, it sure doesn't imply that in its readme.
. :+1: I agree with @vmalloc; too bad about the AGPL licensing. This is the sort of library that a whole host of other programs could make use of otherwise.

pwab:
I can confirm this problem in parts so I'll try to provide as much information as possible:
My machine
Windows 7 x64
Python v3.6.1 on win32
Python stuff

Installed drawille with pip install drawille
Get the ImportError: No module named _curses when trying to import the module
Installed curses‑2.2‑cp36‑cp36m‑win32.whl from pythonlibs
No error anymore but different output in different console-applications (and different font-settings)

Testcode
```python
!/usr/bin/env python
-- coding: utf-8 --
from future import print_function
from drawille import Canvas
from math import sin, radians
c = Canvas()
for x in range(0, 1800, 10):
    c.set(x / 10, 10 + sin(radians(x)) * 10)
print(c.frame())
```
Output
cmd.exe

powershell

conemu

Conclusion
I'm not sure how this depends on font-settings but with conemu (which has a better font- and encoding-support than the other ones) it works fine.. I can confirm this problem in parts so I'll try to provide as much information as possible:
My machine
Windows 7 x64
Python v3.6.1 on win32
Python stuff

Installed drawille with pip install drawille
Get the ImportError: No module named _curses when trying to import the module
Installed curses‑2.2‑cp36‑cp36m‑win32.whl from pythonlibs
No error anymore but different output in different console-applications (and different font-settings)

Testcode
```python
!/usr/bin/env python
-- coding: utf-8 --
from future import print_function
from drawille import Canvas
from math import sin, radians
c = Canvas()
for x in range(0, 1800, 10):
    c.set(x / 10, 10 + sin(radians(x)) * 10)
print(c.frame())
```
Output
cmd.exe

powershell

conemu

Conclusion
I'm not sure how this depends on font-settings but with conemu (which has a better font- and encoding-support than the other ones) it works fine..
